project.teaser: Drastic decrease in transport emissions of 55% by 2030 and 90% by 2050 is required for European cities to reach climate neutrality. This is hindered by inconvenient mobility infrastructure, inadequate services and insufficient governance for short-distance travel, negatively...
project.objective: Drastic decrease in transport emissions of 55% by 2030 and 90% by 2050 is required for European cities to reach climate neutrality. This is hindered by inconvenient mobility infrastructure, inadequate services and insufficient governance for short-distance travel, negatively impacting active modes’ safety and security. REALLOCATE’s main objective is to pave the way towards climate-neutral, safe, inclusive and smart European cities through integrated and innovative sustainable urban mobility solutions that will address the needs of diverse groups and communities, while rebalancing street space allocation. The project will empower 10 twinned Mission Cities (Gothenburg-Tampere, Heidelberg-Utrecht, Lyon-Warsaw, Budapest-Zagreb, Barcelona-Bologna) by providing horizontal thematic expertise, supporting them to build a local innovation ecosystem to develop and deploy zero-emission, shared, inclusive, active and human-centred mobility interventions. Pilots in 15 urban and peri-urban unsafe areas will demonstrate innovative urban space management and reallocation strategies for sustainable modes (with a specific focus on active modes), having in mind safety, inclusivity, affordability and a just transition to climate neutrality overall. Solutions include innovative urban design, behavioural nudging, smart technological and data-driven solutions to reduce actual and perceived road safety risks, all contributing to achieving climate neutrality by 2030. The pilots will be the learning and testing environments for integrated approaches to foster knowledge transfer and collaborative learning to staff in cities through mentoring and capacity building, knowledge exchange, twinning and work shadowing. The project’s impact will be exponentially increased by engaging 10 Cascade Cities in capacity building activities, and providing them with replication packages and guidelines resulting in implementation plans for replicating at least one of the innovative solutions piloted.
project.title: Rethinking the dEsign of streets And pubLic spaces to Leverage the mOdal shift to Climate-friendly Active Transport Everywhere
project.keywords: VRU safety, citizen empowerment, SUMP, SUMI, circularity, road space reallocation, active mobility, AI, decision support tool, capacity building, climate contract, living lab, inclusivity, modal shift

webItem.title: Living with climate change
webItem.alternativeText: The EU Mission on Adaptation to Climate Change is supporting at least 150 European regions in becoming climate-resilient by 2030. The infographic illustrates several examples. In Zagreb, Croatia, 1500 new trees alleviate extreme heat on city streets. In the Canary Islands, better aquifer measurements help islanders manage water resources. In the Berlin-Brandenburg region, authorities will balance increased water demand with an expected 40 % drop in surface water. In the Netherlands, floating houses are one way flood risk is being integrated into urban planning. A pilot in Croatia and Slovakia uses mesh networks and autonomous vehicles to combat wildfires.

webItem.title: Metro metrics
webItem.alternativeText: Cities are home to 75% of EU citizens and generate 70% of CO2 emissions. Transitioning to smart and carbon-neutral cities will mean deploying a range of technologies, strategies and governance tools. The infographic presents the share of urban greenhouse gas emissions by sector: Stationary energy 55%, Transport 26.3%, Waste and wastewater treatment 3.1%, Industrial processes and products use 12.5%, Agriculture, forestry and other land use 2.1%, Other 1%. Source: Self reported data from 105 Mission Cities. Data was not externally verified and not all cities presented comprehensive data on emissions.

category.title: Projects Information Pack
category.description: Article: Selections of projects in their early stages focusing on a specific research theme

article.teaser: In the face of unprecedented challenges posed by climate change, the European Union has embarked on an ambitious journey towards a sustainable and resilient future. The EU Missions on Adaptation to Climate Change and on Climate-Neutral and Smart Cities under Horizon Europe, the EU’s key funding programme for research and innovation, represent significant pillars in this transformative endeavour. This brochure showcases 14 European-funded Mission projects that show the collaborative spirit, innovation and commitment required to address the pressing issues of climate change.

result.description: This deliverable is in the form of a needs assessment report. The deliverable will report the needs, gaps and opportunities identified for each SSML. The deliverable is an outcome of Task 2.1.

result.teaser: The REALLOCATE project, coordinated by University College Dublin and involving 37 partners, is a Mission Project and part of the CIVITAS initiative. The project runs from 1 May 2023 to 30 April 2027 under the call HORIZON-MISS-2022-CIT-01. It addresses the urgent need to...

result.title: D6.1

result.title: D5.1
result.description: This deliverable details the Evaluation & impact framework of the project, on two layers (micro and macro), the mapped tools and mechanisms for its implementation, the definition and materialisation of project KPIs. The deliverable is an outcome of Tasks 5.1, 5.2.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
